TopicTitle: Am I the only one who's creeped out by the Mun?

Articles.Content:
I think that if/when we get weather, it will introduce a whole new level of creepy to some celestial bodies.

Imagine looking out of your spacecraft window on Eve at night, and seeing a gigantic swirling mass of purple gas approaching ominously over the horizon, with distant thunderclaps and lighting illuminating the storm periodically. Perhaps being hit by a storm on eve, with its metallic rain and corrosive fumes could be fatal for Kerbals left out in the open, or could even destroy crafts without sufficient protection. An expedition of Kerbals exploring the area around their base, who's rover gets compromised by rough terrain could be in real danger unless a rescue team gets to them in time...

Sorry, Im rambling on again . But in short, yeah, storms are terrifying.

The Muns poles are weird. Hard to get around with a rover.

that...is exploration, going into the unknown, into the darkness not know when or if you'll ever see the warm shores of kerbin again (besides looking up)

For me, the planets aren't creepy at all. They just present me with pleasing, exotic views.

Well, they do tend to be somewhat "off" though.
The Mun's poles are scary as hell, not least because of the craggy terrain, wonky sunrises and -sets, and resultant long shadows.

Creepy is one thing, but... has anyone experienced even a hint of this while looking at more recent MÃƒÂ¼n terrain? If you're unaware of the meaning behind it, use google images but beware, if you have it, you're in for a nasty surprise. Don't say I haven't warned you.

Man I hate you. I've been vomiting for the last 10 minutes.
I find it quite strange that Ike is always in my way on my transfer to Duna... almost as if it knows...

Duna freaks me out a little bit too.

Due to the close proximity of Ike, just, unnerving.

The only thing I ever found remotely creepy was something I found when I returned to the crash site of a previous Mun lander. The crash site was in a shallow dip in the terrain, and these round RCS tanks were rolling in total silence, ever so slowly along the surface.

I think I have a video of it somewhere - I should post it later.

I find Eeloo the creepiest- it's so far away and so close to cubic light-decades of nothing. Very intimidating.

Duna's also pretty creepy with the face and the SSTV and all that, but it's also the easiest planet to get to, so they kinda cancel out.

... these round RCS tanks were rolling in total silence, ever so slowly along the surface...

I need to see this.

I dont find any of the planets creepy... unless i have the clouds mod. I sent a rover to the south pole of Eve once, the sky was so dark and the feeling was so foreboding, everything seemed to just be waiting behind the next hill. It made it even worse that i was just one small rover in the midst of such a terrifying place.

Now that's creepy.

The Mun feels cozy to me. I think it's because I can look up and see Kerbin like, right there. I did feel a touch nervous during a far-side Mun landing, though.

Jool... that's the one that creeps me out. Being on one of the Joolian moons and seeing that giant green sphere rising on the horizon is an awesome sight, but it's also a powerful remind of just how far away 'home' really is.

For whatever reason flying into very massive objects (gas giants and larger) in space simulators scares me. Black holes in Space Engine give me the creeps. I accidentally flew right up close to one while exploring the center of a globular cluster and proceeded to freak out.

Same with Jool. Aerobraking is a mildly scary experience, its so big I feel like I'm falling in. I'm actually afraid to open the map view in low Jool orbit in case the map camera is inside Jool.

I had a phobia for swimming in deep water as a kid, both from the depth and the drain. I feel like that has something to do with it. Jool is like a bottomless swimming pool with a core just waiting to suck me up like a pool drain.
Here is the only moment that I've found creepy so far. Revisiting a crash site on the Mun and the RCS tanks were still silently, slowly rolling around.
I have the same feeling when i'm on the darkside of the mun, something about the dark sky and nothing to orientate on, but as long as i see a body in the sky everything is good.
Mun, Duna and Eeloo are actually where I feel most at ease. Eve or aerobraking on Jool on the other hand...

Here is the only moment that I've found creepy so far. Revisiting a crash site on the Mun and the RCS tanks were still silently, slowly rolling around.

It's a mass monopropellant migration!

The Mun is plenty creepy to me.

Dark, hostile terrain, very hard to navigate. Also big and high enough gravity to make landings somewhat challenging, yet the gravity is not enough to make rovers move easily.

The devs got the look right, to me it closely resembles the real moon. Which, incidentally, creeped out some of the Apollo astronauts.
After Apollo 18, I've been a bit nervous about the Mun.
Oh yeah, I forgot. Evenings on Eve. It's like this giant sickly green fog that just descends upon you as the terminator approaches. Beautiful to see from space, but terrifying on the ground.

It may be that space travel is so unnatural to humans that everyone is expected to have a phobia of some kind. I haven't read the whole thread, so maybe someone feels the same effect, but my phobia is definitely wierd and hard to explain.

When approaching an another planet for the first time, I get scared of seeing it. Just the idea of establishing first visual contact makes me freak out. Like the first time I went to Duna, I've seen the planet on a lot of pictures and other playthrough videos which was fine, but seeing it closing in from far away makes me very uncomfortable, and we're talking about a game here. If I was on a real mission to Mars, I'm certain that I would be too terrified to look out the window upon arrival.

I cant help it, but those lonely vast lanscapes and starfilled skies give me the shivers, but in a good way. I love those calm and totally relaxed moods, these scenes have to offer. Totally ignites the wish to leave here.
